titleStmt.title: Despatch from Theodore A. Rosenbush to Bancroft Davis, July 15, 1869

bibl.title: Despatch from Theodore A. Rosenbush to Bancroft Davis
Despatches from United States Consuls in Sierra Leone, 1858-1906 T-438

correspAction.persName: Davis, J. C. Bancroft (John Chandler Bancroft), 1822-1907

div1.p: Commercial Agency of the United States of America at Sierra Leone July 15th 1869.
Sir,

In reference to my despatch No 2, dated March 29th 1869, I have now the honor to enclose the further correspondence with the Colonial Government on the subject of the American Barque "Gem" lost off Bulama.
I also forward a parcel, under the seal of this Office, with books, etc: of the deceased Henry Clarke; the inventory of the contents I enclose.

I
H.B. Davis Esque Assistant Secretary Washington D.C.
I further enclose a statement of relief afforded to destitute American Seamen at this Commercial Agency from the 15th of May 1868 to the 30th June 1869, and my Account of expenses, with Vouchers attached, during the same period.

I finally enclose my Account Current with the United States' Government, which shows $73.16 in my favor, for which I have drawn on the Honorable Hamilton Fish, Secretary of State, at 15 days' sight in my own favor.
These are now no destitute seamen under my charge.

I have the honor to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant
Rosenbush

U.S. Commercial Agency
at Sierra Leone.
T. Rosenbush
No 3.
7 Enclosures.
Received
Copy of correspondence with Colal Govmt - Inventory of deceased seaman - Statement of relief, - and Acct current with U.S. Govmt

Colonial Office
Sierra Leone
15th April 1869.
Sir,
With reference to my letter No 257. of the 27th ult, forwarding Copies of Correspondence from the Civil Commandant of Bulama respecting the loss of the U.S. Barque "Gem."
I have the honor to enclose Copy of a letter from the same Officer accounting for the two seamen who were left at the Island when the remainder of the crew of that vessel were sent to this place.

I have the honor to be
Sir,
Your Obedient Servant
(signed) J. J. Kendall
Colonial Secretary
div1.fw:
J. Rosenbush Esqre
U.S. Commercial Agent.
div1.p:
Civil Commandant's Office
Bulama 6 April 1869.
Sir,

On the 22nd March, I informed you that I had sent on to Freetown 7 distressed seamen but that on the morning of the 23rd, I had again to write and say that 2 of these 7 men had been take so ill that they could not with safety to their lives be move on board the Steamer which was on the point of starting. One of these 2 men called "Henry Clarke" has since died, and as the other has recovered sufficiently to be able to go on and as he in anxious to do so by this opportunity; I now send him on in a long boat belonging to one Samuel Coker of Freetown.
I also am desirous of seeing him away for fear of a re-lapse through eating Fruit and running about in the Sun. This man's name is W. H. Tracey.

I have &ca
(sd) J Craig Loggie
Actg Civil Commandment, Bulama.
Commercial Agency of the United States of America at Sierra Leone, 16th April 1869.
Sir,
I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No 310, dated 15th April 1869, enclosing copy of a letter from the Civil Commandant of Bulama.
I beg to reiterate my thanks to His Excellency the Governor-in-Chief for the assistance rendered to the distressed Crew of the wrecked American Barque "Gem".

I have the honor to be, Sir,
Your obedient Servant
"signed" "T. Rosenbush"
J. J. Kendall Esqre. U.S. Vice Coml Agent
Colonial Secretary.
Enclosure
Commercial Agency at Sierra Leone.
Copy of correspondence with Colal Governmt on matter of the Am: Barque "Gem".
No 1.
15th and 16th April 1869.

Colonial Office
Sierra Leone
28th May 1869.
Sir,
I have the honor to forward copy of an Account Sale of the effects of the late Henry Clarke of the U.S. Barque "Gem", who died at Bulama on the 23rd March last.
The amount realized by the Sale has been paid into the Colonial Treasury.
I have also the honor to send certain Books and papers belonging to the same person which have been forwarded by the Civil Commandant of Bulama.

I have the honor to be
Sir,
Your most obedient Servant
(Sd) John Ashwood
For Colonial Secretary
"By His Excellency's Command."
div1.fw:
T. Rosenbush Esqre
U.S. Consular Agent.
div1.p: List of the late Henry Clarkes effects sold by Public Auction at Beaver's Port Bulama on the 29th day of March 1869.

row.cell: 1 Blk HKfs. 1 suit Dil Cloth 1 Blk tie

div1.p: List of the late Henry Clarkes effects sold by Public Auction at Beaver's Port Bulama on the 29th day of March 1869.
Amounting to the Sum of Seven pounds Seven Shillings and Eight Pence Half Penny.
I do hereby Certify that the above is a true and Correct Statement of the amount realized at the Sale of the Effects of the late Henry Clarke.
And I do make this solemn declaration Conscientiously believing the same to be true

(sd) Alfred Walter Lewis
Police Clerk

Declared before me at Bulama this 30th day of April 1869
(Sd) J Craig Loggie
J. P.
Commercial Agency of the United States of America at Sierra Leone May 31st 1869.
Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No 420. dated the 28th instant and enclosing Account Sales of the effects of the late Henry Clarke of the American Barque 'Gem', who died at Bulama on the 23rd of March last.
I have also the honor to acknowledge the receipt of certain Books and papers belonging to the same person which had been forwarded by the Civil Commandant of Bulama.

The amount realized by the sale John Ashwood Esqre which
For Colonial Secretary
which has been paid into the Colonial Treasury I request you will be pleased to place against the expenses incurred by the Colonial Government on account of the crew of the American Barque "Gem" and I shall feel obliged if you will be pleased to furnish me with an account of the same.

I have the honor to be,
Sir,
Your obedient Servant
"Signed" "T. Rosenbush"
U.S. Vice Coml Agent.
div1.ab: Copy of correspondence with Colal Governmt on matter of the Am: Barque "Gem".
div1.p:
Colonial Office
Sierra Leone
12th June 1869
Sir,

With reference to your letter No 5. of the 31st ultimo, acknowledging receipt of certain Books and papers belonging to one "Henry Clarke" late of U.S. Barque "Gem" who died at Bulama. And asking for an account of the expenses incurred by the Colonial Government on account of that vessel.
I have the honor to enclose the necessary Vouchers and to request that you will please pay in the amount to the Colonial Treasury as early as possible.

I have the honor to be
Sir,
Your most obedient Servant
J. J. Kendall
Colonial Secretary
div1.fw:
T. A. Rosenbush Esqre
U.S. Commercial Agent.
div1.p: Commercial Agency of the United States of America at Sierra Leone June 29th 1869
Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No 437 dated the 12th instant, transmitting me an Account of the Expenses incurred by the Colonial Government on account of the American Barque "Gem" lost off Bulama, and showing a balance of Â£11,11,8Â½, due to the Colonial Government.
As requested I herewith pay in the amount to the Colonial Treasury

I have the honor to be, Sir,
Your obedient Servant
"Signed" "T. Rosenbush"
U.S. Vice Coml Agent.
div1.fw:
J. J. Kendall Esqre
Colonial Secretary
div1.ab: Copy of correspondence with Colal Governmt on matter of the Am: Barque "Gem"
div1.p: Inventory of effects belonging to the late Henry Clarke sent to me by the Colonial Secretary:

1 Navigation Book
1 ditto ditto
1 Danish Bible
1 Album with Photographs
1 Guide Book
1 loose Photograph
a Parcel of envelopes and a Map
a Parcel of Blank Books
1 Suffolk Savings Bank Pass Book with $255 to the Credit of Wm Sorenson. also containing a certificate on which certain wages to the deceased are due.
1 Book with written Poetry.
Freetown, Sierra Leone May 31st 1869.

Rosenbush
U.S. Vice Comml Agent
div1.ab: Inventory of effects of the late Henry Clarke, seaman
